ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CRIMINAL INVESTIGATION DEPARTMENT,
ROBINSON ROAD, AND CENTRAL POLICE STATION
(SPECIAL BRANCH) (Access to public during "Police Weeks")


    1. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Secretary-

Column: 548



    (a) if he is aware that the Criminal Investigation Department at Robinson Road and the top floor of the Central Police Station occupied be the Special Branch were not open to the general public during the recent "Police Week", and to state the reasons therefor; and

    (b) whether he will arrange for those two Branches of the Police Force to be open to the public, along with Divisional Police Stations, during future "Police Weeks".

    Mr E. B. David: Yes, Sir. The primary object of "Police Week" was to encourage the general public to familiarise themselves with those sections of the Police Force which are concerned with direct service to the public when they wish to make a report for a request for assistance. The C.I.D. and Special Branch do not come in this category.

    The answer to the second part of the question is in the negative.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, by barring the public from visiting the C.I.D. and the Special Branch, would this not give rise to more suspicion that the allegations of torture are true?

    Mr David: I do not agree with the hon. Member's insinuations.

    Mr Speaker: It would be a matter of opinion.

ACID BOMB THROWING


    2. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Secretary if he is aware of the increasing use of acid bombs by gangsters in gang clashes in which innocent persons have been blinded or injured; and what measures the Government has taken or proposes to take against the use or possession of acid bombs.

    3. Mr John Ede asked the Chief Secretary to state the number of cases of acid throwing which have taken place since 1st January, 1958, the number of convictions in such cases; and whether this form of crime is on the increase.

Column: 549



    Mr David: With your permission, Sir, I will answer questions Nos. 2 and 3 together.

    The crime of using acid to cause hurt is on the increase. Between 1st January and 10th August this year, there were 15 known instances of such use. During the same period, three persons were convicted of offences under the Corrosive Substances Ordinance, 1955. Under this Ordinance, the carrying of acid for the purpose of causing hurt is subject to a maximum penalty of ten years imprisonment and using it for the same purpose a maximum penalty of imprisonment for life and whipping. Acid is very widely used for legitimate commercial purposes and it is extremely difficult therefore to prevent small quantities falling into the wrong hands. The Government is considering, however, whether any practical and effective measures are possible to control its possession and storage. The Government is also considering the imposition of the death penalty for the use of acid to cause hurt.

DIVORCE SUIT NO. 32 OF 1957


    4. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Attorney-General, with reference to his showing cause in Divorce Suit No. 32 of 1957, why the decree nisi pronounced by the Honourable Mr Justice Tan Ah Tah on the 22nd July, 1957, should not be made absolute, to state the grounds upon which he acted; and whether full and proper investigations were duly conducted in Singapore, Port Dickson and Kuala Lumpur with the assistance of experienced officers of the Police Force prior to and after showing cause.

    Mr E. P. Shanks: I intervened in this Divorce Suit, Sir, because, as a result of information I had received and enquiries I made, I believed the decree nisi for dissolution of the marriage had been obtained by reason of material facts not being brought before the Court. Both before and after I intervened, investigations were made in Singapore, Port Dickson and Kuala Lumpur with the assistance of the Police Force and I have no reason to suppose that those enquiries were not both full and proper.

Since the decree was made absolute, that is since the adjudication on my intervention, I have made no further investigation into the matter.

    Mr Speaker: It is a matter of opinion.

PREMISES BUILT AFTER
SEPTEMBER 1947
(To come under Control of Rent Ordinance)


    6. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing if the Government will consider introducing amending legislation with a view to bringing premises built after September, 1947, under the provisions of the Control of Rent Ordinance (Cap. 242).

    Inche Abdul Hamid: The answer is no, Sir.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Is the Minister aware that landlords are taking advantage by charging fantastic rentals and issuing notices to quit because no control of rents is being enforced?

Column: 551



    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, I would suggest to the Member for Queenstown two considerations.

    First, the houses which are now subject to the provisions of the Control of Rent Ordinance were almost all erected prewar at cheaper cost and the controlled rentals can be said to represent a not unreasonable return on capital.

    Second, premises built or completed after 7th September, 1947 were built in the expectation that there would be no control of rents and the relationship between landlords and their tenants was one freely established on such understanding. There is no special reason or emergency (such as existed when rent control was introduced for prewar properties) to justify control of properties erected after September, 1947. Such control would indeed result in stifling private enterprise in building more houses and would merely aggravate the housing situation.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Is the Minister aware that an amount of $500 increase in rentals is demanded by such landlords to exploit their tenants?

OFFICES AND STAFF FOR NEW
DISTRICT COUNCILS
(Request for Statement)


    7. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing whether he will make a statement on the office buildings being constructed and the staff so far made available for the purposes of operating the new District Councils; and whether he is satisfied that the new regional offices are working satisfactorily.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, temporary District Council Offices have already been erected for Serangoon and Katong District Councils and are open for inspection. Each building has a meeting room, secretariat and departmental offices for engineering and building staff, the health and cleansing staff and the assessment and revenue staff. For the Jurong/Bukit Panjang District Council, there is already a permanent office which later will be extended.

Column: 552



    The staffing needs as well as other problems arising from the establishment of District Councils were studied by a working party, which, in its reports recommended additions to the present available Rural Board staff. The report was adopted by Government and the financial provision for the additional staff was approved by this Assembly in April this year.

    Once the District Councils have been in operation for a few months, it will be possible to review the position to ascertain if all the provisions made are in fact adequate. From the measures taken, the District Councils should work satisfactorily.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that the horse now seems to be ready before the cart?

ARREARS OF RATES AND
ASSESSMENTS OF PROPERTIES


    8. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing, with reference to paragraphs 12 to 17 of the Final Report from the Public Accounts Committee ( Sessional Paper No. L.A. 14 of 1957), if he will state -

    (a) the arrears of rates as at (i) 31st December, 1957; and (ii) 30th June, 1958; and

    (b) how many properties have been assessed or re-assessed during the period January to June, 1958; and how many properties remain to be assessed or re-assessed.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, the arrears of rates as at 31st January, 1957 including the arrears carried over from the past year amounted to $1,697,468.28. Arrears for 1957 collected from 1st January to 30th June, 1958 amounted to $772,087.12 and to the end of July $889,339.58. This sum is nearly equal to the sum of $940,006.67 which was the amount of arrears collected for the whole of last year. This improvement was made possible by reorganisation of work and the recruitment towards the end of last year of five of the required new seven bailiffs.

Column: 553



    Regarding (b), 1,771 properties were assessed or re-assessed during the period January to June 1958, at an annual value of just over $1 million, yielding an additional revenue of just over $200,000.

    As regards remaining properties yet to be assessed, it is estimated that there are about 2,000 permanent buildings yet to be assessed of which about 1,500 are new houses in such housing estates as Opera Estate, Glasgow Road, Jalan Kayu, Spring Hill Estate, Sembawang Road, 13½ m.s. Sembawang Road, Sembawang Hill Estate, Thomson Ridge, Bukit Timah Estate and Hong-Kong Park.

    It is on these properties that the Rates Officers, including three newly recruited assistant rates officers, are now concentrating their efforts. This will leave resettlement areas throughout the Rural Board area and many attap houses situated well away from the main roads yet to be assessed. Assessment and reassessment on these localities will follow after the large estates have been completed.

PANDAN FOREST RESERVE


    9. Mr Lim Koon Teck asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing what portion of the 832 acres withdrawn from the Pandan Forest Reserve has been set aside for allocation to persons whose prawn ponds in areas required for development have been or will be acquired by Government.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: The answer to the Member's question is that no portion of the area excised from the Pandan Forest Reserve has been set aside for such allocation, as the manner of allocation has not yet been decided. Due consideration will be given, however, to requests or applications from persons whose prawn ponds are affected by Government acquisitions.

    Mr Lim Koon Teck: Sir, will the Hon. the Minister give an assurance that their claims would have prior consideration?

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, at this juncture, I cannot give such an undertaking.

CITY COUNCIL MASS HEALTH
MOVEMENT
(Instructions to principals and staff of schools)


    10. Mr Lee Kuan Yew asked the Minister for Education whether he gave instructions to the principals and staff of schools in connection with the City Council's mass health movement; and whether he will make a statement in connection with those instructions.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, on 4th July, 1958, the Mayor wrote direct to the school principals asking from one to twenty representatives to attend a meeting at the Victoria Memorial Hall on 7th July, 1958. He did this before any permission was granted to him by me. As the anti-spitting campaign has been conducted in all schools for some years now, it is nothing new and in view of the improper procedure adopted by the Mayor, I gave instructions to the principals not to send representatives to the scheduled meeting. Any campaign in the school should be conducted by my Ministry through the principals who are individually responsible for the administration of their own schools.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Does it follow that the Minister is not in principle against the mass health movement, but that he has taken offence because he has not been first consulted before the schools were approached?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: In principle, I am not against the mass health movement nor against the anti-spitting campaign.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: In that case, does he see any objection to students writing essays in a competition to show why spitting is a bad and pernicious habit?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: It does not form part of the question.

Column: 555



    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: May I put it more bluntly to the not very alert Minister? Does he find any objection to school children writing essays on spitting, if he in fact opposes spitting?

    Mr Speaker: The Minister has answered that it does not form part of the question. It is another question.

GENERAL HOSPITAL
(OUT-PATIENT DEPARTMENT)
(Number of doctors and daily average number of patients)


    11. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Health to state the number of doctors attached to the Out-Patient Department of the General Hospital and the daily average number of patients who attend that Department.

    Mr A. J. Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are 16 doctors attached to the Out-Patient Department of the General Hospital out of which ten are on full-time duty and the remaining six work part-time in the afternoons for a period of two hours.

    The daily average number of patients who attend the Out-Patient Department is 2,300. Of this figure, 1,600 are seen by the Medical Officers of that Department. The remaining 700 attend for repeat treatment such as injections, dressings, etc.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister tell us the number of hours a full-time doctor works in a day?

    Mr Braga: I must have notice of that question.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Minister consider that the ten full-time and six part-time doctors are able to cope with 2,300 patients in one day?

    Mr Braga: As I have already said, 1,600 patients attend in the morning and 700 in the afternoon. For the 16 doctors to deal with this vast number is, I agree, a very heavy task but even if staff can be made available, which is hardly possible at the present time, there is at the moment not sufficient accommodation available for consultation purposes.

Column: 556



    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Can the Minister then tell us what action he proposes to take or has taken to rectify the position?

    Mr Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir, despite all our efforts and despite the introduction of a system of appointments of times, patients insist on arriving early in the morning and there is in consequence an unnatural and severe overcrowding. We are however developing more and more out-patient services and deviating those who seek the services of the General Hospital to new out-patient departments. To this end, Government has so far increased the number of outpatient departments from six in 1954 to 15 during its term of office to date and are constructing three new out-patient clinics, one at Pegu Road, one at Queenstown and another at Bukit Panjang, which should be ready for use by the end of this year. In 1959, three more out-patient departments will be constructed at Buona Vista, Yio Chu Kang Road at the junction of Jalan Kayu, and the third at Nee Soon.

PAYA LEBAR AIRPORT
(Construction of new terminal)


    12. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Communications and Works whether the leading airlines using the Paya Lebar Airport require funds to be spent on a new airport terminal to be constructed to deal expeditiously with the increasing number of passengers and freight carried by air; and whether he will give an undertaking that work on the construction of the proposed new terminal will be started with the least possible delay.

    Mr Francis Thomas: Sir, planning for the improvement or extension of the terminal facilities for the Singapore Airport has been in progress for the past two years. In the course of this, the Director of Civil Aviation has been in close consultation with the airline operators and is fully aware of their needs and requirements in the matter of passengers and baggage handling facilities. To the extent that the provision of such facilities will entail the expenditure of public funds, the answer to the first part of the question is yes.

Column: 557



    In answer to the second part of the question, I can assure the hon. Member that within the financial means of Government, it has always been and still is our intention that terminal facilities will be provided with the least possible delay.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Minister state when the work will start on this building and how long it will take to complete it?

    Mr Francis Thomas: At a later stage this morning, Sir, I will be making a statement on the development of the Airport. To avoid repetition, I suggest that the hon. Member seek clarification after that.

SINGAPORE AIRPORT HOTEL LTD.
(Monthly rent)


    13. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Communications and Works what is the monthly rent payable by the Singapore Airport Hotel Ltd, for the use of the Paya Lebar Airport restaurant premises; whether there are any arrears of rent payable by the tenants and what is the amount.

    Mr Francis Thomas: The concession under which the Singapore Hotel Ltd, operated ended on 30th April this year. Their rent during the period of their concession was $2,833 per month until July 1957 and thereafter $2,874 per month. When the concession terminated, the arrears of rent totalled $51,834.16.

    Mr John Ede: Will the Minister state how these arrears were allowed to accumulate and whether they are recoverable in full?

    Mr Francis Thomas: With regard to their recoverability, the company has gone into voluntary liquidation and what this will produce towards arrears is not yet clear.

    With regard to how they were allowed to accumulate, the hon. Member will appreciate that the Airport Hotel is different in its nature from the ordinary run of hotels. It is not for guests coming to stay at the place in the normal

Column: 558

way; the Airport Hotel is catering for the passengers who are passing through. Consequently, it is closely tied up with the airline operators and it cannot therefore be allowed to close even for a single day. In these circumstances, and bearing in mind that the concessionaire had been successfully operating at the Kallang Airport since 1937, it was thought desirable to give every opportunity of meeting liabilities and by so doing to avoid what might have been urgent difficulties in finding a replacement.

    Mr John Ede: Does the Minister not feel that that reply is thoroughly unsatisfactory? Will he state whether the Singapore taxpayer has to pay for Government's incompetence in not collecting arrears or has the Minister other remedies?

    Mr Francis Thomas: I cannot ask a question in reply to the question. I am not quite sure what the hon. Member means by the Government paying. The Government has suffered a loss but there is no charge that the Government has to meet. The bill has not yet been collected and I cannot say how far it will be collected.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Sir, is the Minister aware that this concessionaire, apart from the legal person in the Singapore Airport Hotel Ltd. - the person behind it - has since 1937 accumulated a fairly vast fortune as a result of work in the old Airport Hotel at the Kallang Airport? Should he not take steps to see that fortunes are not salted away while revenue is owing to the Government?

    Mr Francis Thomas: I am aware of the other interests of the proprietors of the Singapore Airport Hotel but I cannot answer for what the law provides on the question of recovering the arrears. That is in the hands of the liquidator and is being dealt with for the Government by the Treasury. I have no doubt that whatever can and should be collected will be collected but it is not for me at this stage to describe the procedure that will have to be followed.

Column: 559



    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Minister state whether it was the fault of the Treasury that money was not collected month by month or the fault of his Ministry?

    Mr Francis Thomas: I had better perhaps put the hon. Member in the picture as to the general structure of the control and management of such concessions. The day-to-day control and management are exercised by the Airport manager who until recently had an assistant manager to help him. The contracts such as the concessions for the Singapore Hotel are negotiated and completed by the Commissioner of Lands who is the Government's agent for this matter. The accounts are subject to audit scrutiny and the Treasury has, of course, an overall interest in the financial aspects of these contracts. The system is satisfactory, I think, in so far as it distributes responsibility and ensures that proper scrutiny is made. It is perhaps less satisfactory from the point of view of commercial operation as compared with the ordinary run of Government business.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Sir, will the Minister tell us whether any Minister in the Government was approached by the proprietor of the Singapore Airport Hotel Ltd. with a view to writing off the arrears of rent?

    Mr Francis Thomas: Certainly nobody has approached me with such a request and I should imagine that it is inconceivable that anybody would be approached with it.

    Mr John Ede: Does the Minister accept full responsibility for this deplorable state of affairs?

    Mr Francis Thomas: Certainly I do, Sir, I accept full responsibility for everything that falls within my Ministry and for the actions of all officers within my Ministry.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, on the termination of this concession, can the Minister tell us how the present premises are let out since the Singapore Airport Hotel Ltd. has gone into liquidation?

    Mr Francis Thomas: A new concession has been let out which separates the previous concession into two parts: the restaurant and bar form one part and what I think we can call the coffee room on the ground floor is a separate concession now. Up-to-date the concessionaires are both paying their rent punctually.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, why is it then that a public tender is not called for instead of giving it out on a concessional contract?

    Mr Speaker: It seems to be a different question but if the Minister wishes to answer, he may do so.

    Mr Francis Thomas: I think it is a different matter, Sir.

BUKIT TIMAH AND DUNEARN ROADS
(One-way system of traffic)


    14. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Communications and Works whether, and when, it is proposed to introduce a one-way system of traffic along Bukit Timah and Dunearn Roads.

    Mr Francis Thomas: Sir, it is planned that a one-way system for traffic should be introduced along Dunearn and Bukit Timah Roads. This cannot, however, be done until adequate bridges are built across the Bukit Timah Canal. The planning and construction of these bridges is intimately related to a drainage scheme for the whole area. The execution of the drainage scheme depends on the availability of very considerable funds and I am afraid that there is little likelihood that the drainage scheme will go forward in the near future.

CENTRAL WHOLESALE FISH
MARKET
(Request for Statement)


    17. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry if he will make a statement regarding the setting up of a central wholesale fish market.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, various sites have been considered by the Government for the proposed Central Wholesale Fish Market. A site in the delta between the Rochore and Kallang Rivers was first considered but when the Merdeka Bridge project was under way it was found that the bridge had to be built further seaward and the head-room under the bridge in this location was not sufficient to permit access to the delta by the larger fishing vessels. A second site at the southern end of Merdeka Bridge was then considered but it was found to be too costly to build the wholesale fish market here. A third site, at the end of the old runway at Kallang, also considered to be suitable, has, however, been earmarked for the development of a public park. Finally, it has been proposed that the Central Wholesale Fish Market should be temporarily sited at the Telok Ayer Basin. This proposal has not received any support from the Singapore Port Commission and would involve the finding of alternative accommodation for the M.R.N.V.R. which would in itself be very costly. Until, therefore, a suitable permanent site can be found for the central wholesale fish market, there is very little hope of this project materialising.

Column: 564



    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister tell us whether finance is also one of the questions for the delay in establishing this market?
